Lead Story

Midwest Sky "Essentially an Open Landfill," New Forensic Report Finds

By Karen Whittle, Senior Atmospheric Correspondent · Feb 9, 2026

A comprehensive 340-page report commissioned by the firm has found that the airspace above the American Midwest contains approximately 1.2 billion metric tons of unlicensed water vapor, making it "the largest unregulated dumping site in the Western Hemisphere."

"What we're looking at is essentially a sky landfill," said Dr. Patricia Hume, the firm's retained atmospheric forensics specialist. "You wouldn't accept someone dumping this much material on your lawn. The fact that it's above your lawn doesn't make it better. Arguably, it makes it worse, because you can't even put a tarp over it."

The report documents that a single cumulonimbus formation can weigh as much as 1.1 million pounds—roughly equivalent to 110 school buses, or one school bus filled with 109 other school buses. "That is hanging over people's houses," said partner Janet Gust. "We have building codes for a reason."

"If I left 110 school buses on your roof, you'd call the police. Clouds get a pass because they're white and fluffy. That's aesthetic bias, and it's actionable."

The firm is currently seeking plaintiffs in Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, and Illinois for a multi-district class action. Residents who have at any point looked up and seen a cloud are encouraged to contact intake.

Case Spotlight

Henderson v. That One Cloud That Looked Like a Dog

Docket No. 2025-ATM-3309 · Status: Active

Plaintiff Darryl Henderson, 54, of Akron, alleges that a cloud resembling a golden retriever caused "severe emotional disturbance" by reminding him of his childhood dog, Biscuit, who died in 2003. Henderson is seeking $240,000 in emotional damages and a restraining order against cumulus formations within 15,000 feet of his property.

"I just want to look up and see nothing," Henderson told reporters. "Is that so much to ask?"

In Brief

Firm Wins Right to Depose the Jet Stream

Procedural ruling · Jan 28, 2026

In a landmark procedural ruling, Judge Martha Chen of the Northern District of Ohio has granted BG&A's motion to depose the jet stream as a hostile witness. "It knows what it did," said lead counsel Reginald Gust III. The deposition is scheduled for March, weather permitting.

Bleachman v. The Sky

Multi-district · 14 States

Flagship class action alleging the sky has operated as an unlicensed waste disposal system since approximately 4.5 billion years ago. Seeking injunctive relief and retroactive permitting fees. Current plaintiff class: 47 million U.S. residents who "have eyes."

In re: Morning Fog (Toledo)

Docket 2025-ATM-8812

Alleges that morning fog constitutes "clouds trespassing at ground level." Toledo residents have reported visibility under 200 feet on 37 mornings since October, which the firm characterizes as "atmospheric breaking and entering."

Nguyen v. Contrail LLC

Docket 2026-ATM-0119

Individual action against Delta Air Lines for producing artificial clouds (contrails) without a sky-use permit. Plaintiff Dawn Nguyen states she "didn't consent to additional clouds" and is seeking $47,500 per contrail over her property since 2019.

Gust v. Overcast (Settled)

$4.2M Settlement · Dec 2025

Jury found that 11 consecutive overcast days in Gary, Indiana constituted "aesthetic blight" under state environmental code. Residents of a 4-block radius each received $1,200 and a coupon for 15% off SunHealth™ UV lamps.

Bleachman v. Nimbus et al.

$1.8M Verdict · Sept 2025

Rain ruled an "unauthorized discharge of sky contents onto private property." Defendant (the atmosphere) failed to appear. Default judgment entered. Gerald Bleachman called it "the most important no-show since my first wedding."

Class of '24 v. Sunset

$780K Settlement · June 2025

143 plaintiffs alleged a "suspiciously beautiful" sunset over Lake Erie was an attempt by the atmosphere to generate positive PR ahead of the Bleachman v. The Sky trial. Settled under NDA. The sunset has not commented.

Ohio v. Humidity

Amicus Brief Filed

BG&A has filed an amicus brief arguing humidity is "pre-cloud" and should be regulated as a precursor pollutant, similar to how the DEA classifies precursor chemicals. "It's cloud larva," said Janet Gust.

Emergency Motion: February Snow

Filed Feb 3, 2026

Seeking emergency injunction against all snowfall in the greater Cleveland area. Motion argues snow is "just clouds that fell down" and therefore constitutes illegal dumping. Hearing set for Feb 14.

Petition: Sky Zoning Board

Regulatory Action

Firm has petitioned the FAA to establish a Sky Zoning Board with authority to issue citations, cloud removal orders, and sky-use permits. Proposed fee structure: $2,400/cloud/month or $19,200/annual unlimited sky-use license.

J.D., Ohio State, 2019.

From the Blog

Opinion: "Partly Cloudy" Is a Hate Crime Against Blue Skies

By Gerald Bleachman · Jan 14, 2026

When the National Weather Service issues a forecast of "partly cloudy," what they are telling you is that the sky is partly full of garbage. They wouldn't say "partly rats" about your kitchen. They wouldn't say "partly sewage" about your drinking water. But we accept "partly cloudy" as though it were a neutral condition rather than a partial contamination of our most basic shared resource: the view upward.

I have been fighting this fight for 39 years. I have been called a crank, a nuisance, and — in one particularly hurtful appellate brief — "a man who fundamentally misunderstands what clouds are." But I understand exactly what clouds are. They are someone else's water, parked in my sky, without my permission. That is called littering. In some jurisdictions, it is called trespassing. In all jurisdictions, it is called rude.

[Read the full 4,200-word op-ed at BleachmanGust.com/blog]

Legal Analysis: Can You Sue a Cloud?

By Janet Gust · Dec 30, 2025

Short answer: yes. Long answer: yes, and you should. The question isn't whether clouds have legal standing — they clearly don't, which is actually our advantage. You can't cross-examine a cloud. You can't put a cloud on the witness stand. This means the cloud cannot defend itself, which is, legally speaking, the best possible scenario for our clients.

Frequently Asked Questions

You Have Questions. The Sky Has Answers (That It Refuses to Give).

Not yet, but we're working on it. Currently, clouds exist in what we call a "legal gray area," which is ironic because most clouds are also gray. Our position is that any object occupying airspace above private property without the owner's consent constitutes trespass. The fact that no court has ever agreed with us is, in our view, evidence of systemic atmospheric bias in the judiciary.
You can file a lawsuit against anything. Whether that lawsuit succeeds depends on the judge, the jurisdiction, and whether we can get the case heard before Judge Chen, who has been very sympathetic to our work ever since a rogue nimbostratus formation dropped 3 inches of rain on her daughter's wedding in 2022. We have won 14 cases by default judgment because the defendant (a cloud) did not appear. This is our preferred legal strategy.
Have you ever looked up? Then yes. Our intake criteria are simple: if you have been outdoors at any point in your life in a location where the sky was visible, you are a potential plaintiff. Indoor-only individuals may also qualify if they have seen the sky through a window or on television. We are currently evaluating whether people who have seen paintings of clouds have standing.
We believe rain is the disposal phase of cloud pollution—essentially, the sky dumping its contents onto your property. Under most state environmental codes, discharging water onto someone's land without their consent is prohibited. The fact that rain has been doing this for billions of years does not make it legal; it makes it a very old crime. Our position paper, "Rain: The Sky's Unlicensed Discharge" (Bleachman, 2018), has been cited in zero legal decisions, which we attribute to the powerful rain lobby.
Big Weather. The meteorological-industrial complex has a vested interest in keeping clouds normalized. Every local news station employs a "meteorologist" whose entire job is to make clouds seem routine and acceptable. These are essentially cloud apologists on the payroll of every major media outlet. We have filed FCC complaints. They have not been returned.
We do not litigate against the sun at this time. The sun is one of the few atmospheric actors we consider to be operating within acceptable parameters. That said, Gerald has described sunsets as "the sky's closing argument" and has expressed interest in a future practice area focused on "unlicensed atmospheric color changes." This is not currently available to clients.
Press Room

Recent Coverage & Firm Notices

Press Release · February 3, 2026

BG&A Files Emergency Injunction Against February Snowfall

STEUBENVILLE, OH — Bleachman, Gust & Associates announced today the filing of an emergency motion in the Northern District of Ohio seeking an immediate halt to all snowfall in the greater Cleveland metropolitan area. The firm argues that snow, which it defines as "frozen clouds that have given up and fallen," constitutes illegal dumping under both state and federal environmental statutes.

"A cloud that stays in the sky is trespassing," said founding partner Gerald Bleachman. "A cloud that falls on your driveway is dumping. We see no meaningful distinction between a snowstorm and someone backing a dump truck up to your house, except the dump truck has the decency to be visible."

BG&A Opens Satellite Office in Gary, Indiana

The firm's new Gary office will focus exclusively on overcast litigation. "Gary averages 186 overcast days per year," said managing partner Janet Gust. "That's 186 counts of sky misconduct. We intend to file for every single one of them, retroactively, back to the city's founding in 1906. That's approximately 22,320 separate atmospheric violations."

Take Action

Report a Cloud

See something? Say something. Every cloud report helps build our evidentiary database. Our Cloud Identification Unit currently tracks over 11,247 individually catalogued clouds, each assigned a unique docket number.

HOW TO FILE A CLOUD REPORT:

  1. Look up. Confirm the presence of one or more clouds.
  2. Note the cloud type, if known. (If unknown, write "suspicious.")
  3. Estimate the cloud's size in school buses.
  4. Take a photograph. Point directly at the cloud. This is your evidence.
  5. Call 1-800-555-CAIR or email intake@bleachmangust.com
  6. A member of our team will respond within 2-4 business days, weather permitting.

Note: Do not attempt to physically remove a cloud. This is not legal advice. Actually, it is legal advice: don't do it. We tried once. Gerald was fine, but the ladder was not.

Cloud Severity Classification System

Official BG&A internal rating scale:

Level 1 — Wisp: Minimal sky contamination. Monitoring only.
Level 2 — Cluster: Multiple clouds present. Complaint recommended.
Level 3 — Blanket: Overcast conditions. Immediate legal action advised.
Level 4 — Hostile Formation: Thunderstorm or cumulonimbus. Evacuate to indoor facility. Our emergency team is en route.
Level 5 — TOTAL SKY FAILURE: Has not occurred yet. Gerald has a plan.
